questions.text: From the dense vegetation near the highway, the police have found the remains of a burnt body. The location was discovered with the help of a sniffer dog, as they were tracing a 25-year-old IT worker who had gone missing the night before. To determine the identity of the victim, the team needs to gather a suitable sample. Which type of tissue from a charred body is most effective for identification purposes?
What is the substance identified by Barberio's test, which was conducted on the stains from a sexual assault incident involving an 18-year-old female and a 20-year-old male?
Identify the fingerprint pattern shown in the image:

A deceased male was brought to the morgue for a post-mortem examination. His relatives reported that he had a tattoo over his skin, which was not found on examination. Which of the following structures would you examine?
questions.explanation:
Age of tattoo
  • Firm union, reddish/bluish scar: 5-6 days
  • Pale, soft and sensitive (tender): 2 weeks-2 months
  • Tough, brownish, glistening, wrinkled and little tender: 2-6 months
  • Tough, white, glistening and non-tender: > 6 months

Dyes Used
  • Common dyes: Indigo, cobalt, carbon, vermilion, cadmium, selenium, Prussian blue and Indian ink
  • Black, blue and red dyes are most commonly employed
  • Depth of penetration: 50-3000 times a minute
  • Pigment can migrate to nearby lymph nodes (Option C)

Erasure Methods

Surgical methods:

  • Dermabrasion (e.g., tannic acid, silver nitrate, trichloroacetic acid)
  • Complete excision and skin grafting

Non-surgical methods:

  • Production of burns by means of red hot iron
  • Scarification
  • Using carbon dioxide snow
  • Electrolysis
  • Caustic or corrosive substances
  • Chronic eczema may cause tattoo designs to disappear

questions.text: Match the following weapons with the potential injuries they may cause: A. Axe 1. Incised wound B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident) 2. Train track bruise C. Blade 3. Grazed abrasion D. Lathi 4. Chop wound
questions.explanation:
Blunt Force Injuries

Sharp Force Injuries
  • Abrasion: Superficial damage to the skin (scraping, rubbing off the outer layer).
  • Contusion: Bruise caused by blood vessels rupturing under the skin due to impact.
  • Laceration: Irregular tear in the skin or tissue caused by crushing or blunt trauma.
  • Fractures/Dislocations: Breaks or misalignment of bones due to strong blunt impact.
  • Incision: A clean-cut wound where the length is greater than the depth.
  • Stab Wound: A deep wound where the depth is greater than the length.
  • Chop Wound: A deep wound often associated with underlying fractures caused by heavy-bladed tools like an axe.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image ?
questions.explanation:
Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture) (Option C)

Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture) (Option A ruled out)
  • The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers.
  • The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force.
  • No depression of bone fragments.
  • Involves the separation of cranial sutures.
  • More common in children.
  • Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures.
  • Commonly seen at the sagittal suture.

Causes:

  • Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents).
  • Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards.

Causes:

  • Blunt trauma to the head.
  • Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation.

Narrow fissure skull fracture

Depressed Fracture

(Option B ruled out)

Comminuted Fracture

(Option D ruled out)

Gutter Fracture
  • Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain.
  • Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks).
  • The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury.

Variants:

  • Elevated Fracture: One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe.
  • Pond Fracture: Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade.
  • Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments.
  • Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries).
  • It may occur alongside other fractures (e.g., fissured or depressed fractures).
  • Spider web-like patterns on an X-ray are characteristic of comminuted fractures.
  • In severe cases, bone fragments may penetrate the brain or become displaced.
  • A groove or channel is formed in the skull bone, often due to an oblique bullet wound.
  • Frequently associated with comminuted and depressed fractures of the inner skull table.
  • Bone fragments can cause injury to the meninges or brain.

Depressed fracture

Comminuted fracture

Gutter fracture

questions.text: Under which doctrine is the doctor not responsible when a patient with life-threatening injuries arrives at the casualty without time for consent and the doctor initiates life-saving procedures with the utmost care, but unfortunately, the patient still succumbs to death?
questions.explanation:
Doctrine Application
Res ipsa loquitur Presumption of negligence
Doctrine of anticipation Emergency life-saving treatment without consent
Doctrine of extended consent Consent extended to related findings during surgery

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
Marbling

Definition

Refers to a characteristic pattern in the skin caused by decomposition.

Mechanism

After death, bacteria spread through blood vessels, decomposing hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin, which causes greenish or reddish-brown staining of the vessel walls.

Pattern

Marbled pattern follows a linear branching pattern, resembling tree branches, which initially appears red and later transitions to a greenish hue.

Onset and Timing
  • Begins to develop 24 hours after death.
  • Becomes prominent by 36-48 hours.

Color Changes Over Time

Skin’s reddish-green marbling may turn dark green or nearly black within 3 to 4 days.

Areas of Marbling

Shoulders, roots of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest, and neck.

Medicolegal Importance

Helps in determining the time since death

Image

Feature

Marbling

Filigree Burns

Nature

Postmortem pattern in the skin caused by bacterial decomposition.

Superficial thin, irregular and tortuous skin markings caused by lightning or electrical discharge.

Onset

Starts within 24 hours after death.

Appears within minutes to an hour of the electrical accident.

Colour

Starts reddish-green and eventually dark green or black.

Red

Site of Occurrence

Blood vessels

Skin surface

Medicolegal Importance

Helps determine the time since death.

Indicates electrical injuries or lighting.

Image

questions.text: Which confirmatory test is utilized by forensic experts to establish the presence of a bloodstain at a crime scene?
questions.explanation:
Test

Description

Takayama Test

Detects hemoglobin by forming red, feathery crystals of pyridine ferroprotoporphyrin.

Teichmann Test

Converts hemoglobin to hemin, creating brownish-yellow rhomboid crystals, confirming blood presence.

Test

Description

Precipitin Test

Identifies species origin through antibody-antigen reactions, using antisera specific to human blood.

HemaTrace Test

Uses monoclonal antibodies to detect human hemoglobin, showing a visible pink band for confirmation.

questions.text: All of the following are used in the identification of a dead body except?
questions.explanation:
Samples Collected from Dead Bodies

Fresh Dead Bodies
  • Use unclotted 10 mL blood in a sterile EDTA tube as the preferred DNA source.
  • EDTA buffers inhibit DNA-degrading nucleases.
  • Clotted blood is unsuitable due to WBC settling.

Intermediate Postmortem
  • Brain tissue is a good DNA source.

Advanced Decomposition
  • Hard tissues like bone and teeth (vascular pulp) are ideal for DNA extraction.
  • Recommended materials: muscle, spleen, bone marrow (femur), and molars.
  • Postmortem samples are less reliable due to DNA degradation and putrefaction.

Samples Collected from Living Subjects

Blood
  • Collect 5 mL venous blood in an EDTA vacutainer (purple stopper) and mix gently.
  • Avoid heparin as it interferes with PCR.
  • Preserve at 2–8°C (do not freeze).

Buccal Epithelial Cells
  • Use buccal swabs as a noninvasive, inexpensive, and easy alternative for DNA collection.
  • Swab the mouth for 10 seconds without touching the tip, then place in a receptacle to dry.

Hair Follicles with Roots
  • Pluck 10–20 hairs from the head.
  • Roots contain nuclear DNA; shafts contain mitochondrial DNA.
  • Naturally shed or cut hairs may still provide DNA from nucleated corneocytes.

Samples Encountered in Forensic Practice

Blood

Found as EDTA/heparinized, clotted, or stains on cloth, wood, or tiles.

Semen

Found as stains on cloth, paper, or floors.

Hair

Found on the head, body, or pubic regions.

Tissue

Includes bone marrow, muscle, spleen, or fingernail scrapings.

Saliva

Found on mouth swabs, cigarette butts, envelopes, or glasses.

questions.text: Following the death of a 40-year-old male patient, his relatives mention that he had a tattoo on his body. However, upon autopsy, no tattoo is observed on the skin. What is the best location to check for the presence of the tattoo?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Lymph node

questions.text: Identify the following image.
A vegetable vendor with no criminal history went missing and was found dead a week later with advanced decomposition. How would you identify the body?
Identify the finding that is seen in antemortem drowning?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Cadaveric spasm, also known as cataleptic rigidity or instantaneous rigor, is an ante-mortem phenomenon occurring immediately at the time of death.

Mechanism

ATP depletion in a specific group of muscles that were contracted just before death.

Features
  • Muscles that were in use at the time of death remain stiff and rigid immediately after death.
  • No primary relaxation phase, but secondary relaxation occurs during decomposition.
  • Cannot be artificially induced, making it an exclusively ante-mortem finding.

Medico-Legal Importance

Cadaveric spasm helps in determining whether drowning was ante-mortem or post-mortem.

In cases of antemortem drowning, the spasm can cause the victim to tightly grip objects like weeds or mud, indicating they were alive and struggling before death. This provides evidence of active efforts during the drowning process.

 

 

Conversely, if no cadaveric spasm is present, it may suggest post-mortem immersion, indicating that the body was placed in water after death.
